formal_accuser.name: Catherine femme Jean Demenge Willaume
formal_accuser.relationship_to_accused: Previously denounced her in 1609; her denunciation was referenced at start of trial. Catherine was executed and denounced Jennon at her own execution.

confession.seduction_context: She was out with a cart when Persin seduced her; he promised her riches and she agreed to serve him because of her desire to have money and to relieve her poverty. At the time 'elle estoit fort pauvre et necessiteuse, que son marit s'en alloit le plus souvent yvrogner en taverne, et la laissoit avec ses enfans sans avoir ung morceau de pain' (she was very poor and in need, her husband often went drinking at the tavern, leaving her with her children without a morsel of bread). She said he had 'meschamment trompé, le vilain bot qu'il est' (wickedly deceived her, the ugly toad that he is).
powder_types: magical powder used to harm and to heal
sabbat_activities: making hail (which she refused because of her own poverty)
beaten by master and other witches for refusing to do evil

witnesses.name: Jennon femme Demenge Anthoine de la Vacherie
Marguitte femme Didier Thiebault de la Vacherie
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: neighbor; husband caught Jennon's husband stealing grain

testimony.quarrel_subject: Jennon's husband was caught stealing grain by Marguitte's husband and forced to make reparation; Jennon was refused butter she wanted to buy; witness's son Mengeon refused to do carting work for Jennon
testimony.threat_quote: Jennon called Perrin (the cunning man who identified her) 'un meschant homme' and threatened to throw stones at him if he returned

harms_alleged.target_relationship: being fattened for Rembault Jean Girard of Ramberviller

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: after son refused to do carting

witnesses.name: Mengeon Claude Gerard
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: employer (refused to employ her after incident)

testimony.quarrel_subject: Replaced Jennon's daughter as chambriere with another girl, partly due to mother's reputation

witnesses.name: Hydoulx Grand Didier de La Vacherie

testimony.quarrel_subject: Contracted to cart wood that George Bastien bought from Jennon's husband; she wanted someone else to have the job
testimony.threat_quote: menaca le deposant, et dit que puis qu'il avoit fait ledit marché, il ne charroyeroit guiere avant sans fortune

witnesses.name: Catherine femme Nicolas Moullot de la Vacherie

testimony.quarrel_subject: Unable to get payment for flour sold to Jennon, who often asked for credit; witness told husband to refuse her in future
testimony.threat_quote: avoit beau a aller en pellerinages, et qu'elle avoit encor peu de mal de par le diable

testimony.quarrel_subject: Various disputes with Jean Jeandey leading to killing of his animals and reducing him to great poverty
Jennon was caught stealing apples from his house 9-10 years earlier
At mill, he would not let her mill first
testimony.threat_quote: qu'il ne la voulloit laisser mouldre la premiere mais quelle luy garderoit ung passe

witnesses.name: Jean Demenge Villaume
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: victim; husband of Catherine who denounced Jennon at her own execution

testimony.quarrel_subject: His wife Catherine had accused Jennon of witchcraft at Catherine's own execution

timeline.subject: Catherine femme Jean Demenge Willaume
timeline.details: Copy of denunciation made by Catherine femme Jean Demenge Willaume (date approximate - 1609)

timeline.subject: Jennon femme Claudon Hennemant
timeline.details: Depositions taken at request of procureur d'office for M. d'Etival

timeline.subject: Jennon femme Claudon Hennemant
timeline.details: First interrogation; she said she was about 50, daughter of Colas and Margo Choppat of Ayefosse; married about 30 years, always resident at la Vacherie

timeline.subject: Jennon femme Claudon Hennemant
timeline.details: Confrontations with witnesses (date possibly mistakenly written as 11 April in document)

timeline.subject: Jennon femme Claudon Hennemant
timeline.details: Procureur d'office asks for question ordinaire

timeline.subject: Jennon femme Claudon Hennemant
timeline.details: Change de Nancy agrees to torture

timeline.subject: Jennon femme Claudon Hennemant
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture at abbey of Etival; withstood thumbscrews but confessed when racked harder

timeline.subject: Jennon femme Claudon Hennemant
timeline.details: Further interrogation; provided more details about seduction and sabbat

timeline.subject: Jennon femme Claudon Hennemant
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves death sentence

timeline.subject: Jennon femme Claudon Hennemant
timeline.details: Sentence carried out at Saint Dié

accomplices_named.name: Mengeon Grand Didier
accomplices_named.context: Seen at sabbat; now living at Herbaville

prior_accusations.context: Made denunciation in 1609; this denunciation was referenced at start of 1616 trial. Catherine was executed and denounced Jennon at her own execution.

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon femme Claudon Hennemant (to Hydoulx Grand Didier)
notable_quotes.french: qu'il n'avoit guierre de patience, et estoit trop chault
notable_quotes.english: that he had little patience and was too hot-headed
notable_quotes.context: When Hydoulx confronted her about bewitching his horse, threatening her with an axe

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon femme Claudon Hennemant (about Perrin the cunning man)
notable_quotes.context: Her response when told that Perrin had identified her as bewitching the oxen

notable_quotes.speaker: Hydoulx Grand Didier (threat to Jennon)
notable_quotes.french: menaca le deposant, et dit que puis qu'il avoit fait ledit marché, il ne charroyeroit guiere avant sans fortune
notable_quotes.english: threatened the deponent and said that since he had made the contract, he would not cart long without misfortune
notable_quotes.context: Jennon's threat when Hydoulx contracted to cart wood she wanted someone else to have

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon femme Claudon Hennemant (to Jacquotte)
notable_quotes.french: avoit beau a aller en pellerinages, et qu'elle avoit encor peu de mal de par le diable
notable_quotes.english: it was no use going on pilgrimages, and that she still had little harm from the devil
notable_quotes.context: Said to Jacquotte about her injured finger

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon femme Claudon Hennemant (about horse)
notable_quotes.french: que la malle mort le puisse manger
notable_quotes.english: may the evil death eat it
notable_quotes.context: Threat made when Marguitte was taking a horse to pasture; horse died 2-3 days later

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon femme Claudon Hennemant (to Jean Mareschal at mill)
notable_quotes.french: qu'il ne la voulloit laisser mouldre la premiere mais quelle luy garderoit ung passe
notable_quotes.english: that he would not let her mill first but that she would keep a turn for him
notable_quotes.context: Threat at mill when Jean Mareschal would not let her mill first; the child his wife was carrying died

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon femme Claudon Hennemant (confession under torture)
notable_quotes.french: pour le desir qu'elle avoit d'avoir de l'argent, et par ce moyen subvenir a ses necessitez et pauvretez
notable_quotes.english: for the desire she had to have money, and by this means to relieve her needs and poverty
notable_quotes.context: Why she agreed to serve Persin

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon femme Claudon Hennemant (confession)
notable_quotes.french: quand elle soubhastoit quelque desplaisir ou malladie, led Persin son maitre executoit sa volonté, pourveu quelle y ait donne son consentement
notable_quotes.english: when she wished some displeasure or sickness, said Persin her master executed her will, provided that she gave her consent
notable_quotes.context: Describing how the devil carried out her wishes

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon femme Claudon Hennemant (further interrogation)
notable_quotes.french: elle estoit fort pauvre et necessiteuse, que son marit s'en alloit le plus souvent yvrogner en taverne, et la laissoit avec ses enfans sans avoir ung morceau de pain
notable_quotes.english: she was very poor and in need, her husband often went drinking at the tavern, and left her with her children without a morsel of bread
notable_quotes.context: Explaining her desperate situation at the time of seduction

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon femme Claudon Hennemant (about Persin)
notable_quotes.french: mais qu'il l'a meschamment trompé, le vilain bot qu'il est
notable_quotes.english: but that he wickedly deceived her, the ugly toad that he is
notable_quotes.context: Her bitter reflection on being deceived by the devil

had employed Jennon's daughter as chambriere

economic_context.details: Multiple economic tensions: Jennon's husband caught stealing grain and forced to make reparation; Jennon often asked for credit for flour and could not pay; she was 'fort pauvre et necessiteuse' with a husband who 's'en alloit le plus souvent yvrogner en taverne' leaving her with children 'sans avoir ung morceau de pain.' Economic desperation was explicitly cited as reason for turning to devil. Disputes over carting contracts. Employed as agricultural laborer. Caught stealing apples 9-10 years earlier. Pig damaged her meix (property). She wanted particular carting job to go to someone else (possibly relative or friend). Daughter worked as chambriere but was fired due to mother's reputation.

third_parties.name: Perrin from Raon
third_parties.relationship_to_accused: adversary; cunning man who identified her as witch
third_parties.relationship_to_witness: consulted by Marguitte to identify who bewitched oxen
third_parties.context: Cunning man from Raon who came to see sick oxen and said the woman who had bewitched them would come to their house that day without fail. Jennon was the only visitor. She called him 'un meschant homme' and threatened to throw stones at him if he came back, but failed to do so although she saw him several times later.

third_parties.name: Colas Ferry
third_parties.context: Came upon the scene when Mengeon saw Jennon behaving strangely; also noticed the tremendous smell of sulphur

third_parties.name: Rembault Jean Girard
third_parties.relationship_to_witness: employer of Marguitte for fattening oxen
third_parties.context: Of Ramberviller; owned the 6 oxen that were being fattened and became ill

third_parties.name: George Bastien

third_parties.name: Jennon's daughter
third_parties.context: Employed as chambriere by Nicolas Ratonge but replaced by another girl, partly due to mother's reputation. This angered Jennon.

third_parties.context: Refused to do carting for Jennon previous winter, then lost a fine calf

third_parties.name: Jean Collert
third_parties.context: Jennon caught stealing apples from his house 9-10 years earlier; she allegedly then killed his mare and cow

third_parties.name: Claudon Hennemant

third_parties.context: Left with Jennon without bread when husband went drinking; mentioned in confession as part of her desperate poverty

extraction_metadata.notes: Complete trial record with clear timeline from April 10 to May 31, 1616. Document notes that depositions stop after witness #7 with note 'MS lost or microfilming error?' but interrogation reveals at least 20 witnesses total. Witnesses 8-20 are identified by name during confrontations but their full testimony is not included in the document. Economic desperation is a central theme, explicitly cited in confession as reason for turning to devil. Jennon practiced healing (advised about sick pig, used powder to heal and harm). Trial shows clear progression: denunciation (1609) -> informations (April 1616) -> interrogation (May 10) -> torture request/approval -> torture and confession (May 17) -> death sentence request/approval -> execution (May 31). Change de Nancy consulted twice: approved torture May 13, approved death May 20. Executed at Saint Dié rather than local venue. Notable that she was identified by cunning man Perrin from Raon. Age given as 'about 50' in interrogation but first witness described her as 'c. 60', suggesting uncertainty. Multiple quarrels over economic matters: grain theft, butter, credit for flour, carting contracts, employment of daughter. Wolf predation mentioned as unusual (targeted specific cow in common herd). Confession includes sabbat attendance (only once, beaten for refusing evil), accomplices named, devil called 'Mre Persin', used powder for maleficia and healing. Prior accusation 7 years earlier (1609) by Catherine who later executed and denounced Jennon again at her own execution. Trial demonstrates intersection of poverty, reputation, economic disputes, and cunning folk. Married about 30 years, always resident at La Vacherie. Daughter of Colas and Margo Choppat of Ayefosse.
